Scenarios by which a "Yes " may occur? The most probable/foreseeable is (a) stalemate of negotiations on the Dispute Resolutions chapters of the Agreement, and (b) intervention by Executive Order before expiry of the pre-established timeline for negotiation. 
Either condition would, in normal circumstances, be highly unlikely, but these are not normal circumstances:
(a) the clauses of Chapters 4, 19 and 20 related to multilateral resolution methods were established to ensure non-abuse by a single party (the one with the strongest leverage). The US has stated that multilateral resolution processes undermine its sovereignty and removal is non-negotiable. Mexico has acquiesced. Canada has stated that multilateral resolution is mandatory to protect its interests. It will take elegant negotiation at the presidential/prime ministerial level for this to be resolved - something which I have difficulty picturing within the timeframe
(b) political pressure to reverse declining approval ratings, together with repeated declamation of the Agreement, and personal traits for action and to avoid nuance, all add to the probability of a pre-emptive Executive Order. 
Normal conditions do not apply.

NAFTA, indeed, is a withdraw-able, multinational agreement. Per Article II, Section 2 of the United States Constitution and stare decisis, no explicit wording prohibit the US president from submitting the letter of notice to withdraw from treaties (including NAFTA). However, it'd be challenging for Trump to actually complete the NAFTA withdrawal as the U.S. Constitution gives the president broad authority to negotiate treaties and conduct foreign policy while Congress shares responsibility and accountability per separation of power scheme.

The question seems clear - will the US issue notice under Article 2205. It is unlikely that Mexico will. The US or Canada may, should either country chose to up the anti in brinkmanship (which could be cancelled, potentially), or a leader simply want to make a political statement. However, all signals are that the negotiating teams are acting in good faith and have the intellect and patience to get amendments to the deal right. It also makes sense that any re-branding would be by amendment rather than replacement of the agreement. A meaningful agreement is as significant to economies of the three countries involved as it was when created in the Reagan era - possibly more so with the current risk of a receding middle class of income earners, consumers and tax-base.
That said, there may uncertainties related to:
1. a risk of failure of any negotiation, despite the best of intentions of all parties
2. political priorities of the US government in the month or two prior to mid-term elections
3. if Article 2205 can be filed by Presidential Order, then political priorities of the US Executive. (Can any forecaster clarify whether this is possible?)

...Top White House officials appeared split on whether they would proceed at all if Canada didn’t sign on to the deal. Trump left open the possibility of cutting Canada out of the final deal, which he said would replace NAFTA. But U.S. Trade Representative Robert E. Lighthizer told reporters later that every effort would be made to include Canada, even if it took weeks or longer for them to sign on to changes. And Mexican leaders also said Canada must be included in the deal.
          There were also signs of division about what the agreement means for NAFTA. Trump said that the new deal with Mexico would lead to the termination of NAFTA and that he would rename it the United States — Mexico trade agreement. Lighthizer cautioned that no decision had been made about this.
          Lighthizer said the White House planned to send Congress a letter by Friday that formally starts a 90-day process for changing NAFTA. He said it was still unclear what precisely the letter might say. It could say the U.S. has reached a deal with Mexico, he said, or it could say that an agreement has been reached with Mexico in the hopes that Canada would be brought into the package at a later date.
          And there were fundamental questions marks about the role of Canada and the future of a regional trade agreement. Peña Nieto, speaking with the president on speaker phone, mentioned several times that he wanted Canada to be involved. Marcelo Ebrard, who has been chosen as Foreign Minister in the new Mexican administration, also said in a statement that while the agreement was a “positive step” Canada was “indispensable for being able to renew the treaty.”
          ...The surprising scenes of Trump and the Mexican president congratulating each other in front of news cameras on successful bilateral negotiations that left Canada out appeared designed, in part, to pressure Canada.
          Peña Nieto wrote on Twitter that he has spoken with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and expressed the “importance of rejoining the process, with the goal of concluding the trilateral negotiation this week.”  Peña Nieto’s administration wants to reach an agreement soon so that the Mexican Congress has enough time to ratify the deal before President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador takes office on Dec. 1.
          ...Leading congressional Republicans cautiously welcomed Trump’s announcement, while making clear that they would not embrace a NAFTA 2.0 that leaves out Canada. “A final agreement should include Canada” in order to ensure that NAFTA continues to benefit American businesses and families, said Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin G. Hatch (R-Utah).
          ...Although trade deals are complex affairs that typically require years of glacial bargaining, administration officials initially hoped to finish the job by the end of 2017. They failed to meet that ambitious timetable and also blew through revised deadlines for the end of March and late May.  This time, the deadline may be real, given a congressional requirement for 90 days notice of an impending trade deal. If the administration doesn’t formally notify Congress that it has reached agreement with both Canada and Mexico by the end of August, Peña Nieto, the outgoing Mexican president, will not be able to sign it.

(up 5). Now that it's clear that Canada and Mexico are excluded from the steel & aluminum tariffs, let's think what might be the impact of the tariff saga on the outcome of this question. Trump threatened to impose these tariffs on the US NAFTA partners if no NAFTA deal to his liking is reached - and then backed off. How to read this? On the one hand, Trump did show that he is willing to break - or at least make more costly - established free-trade links. On the other hand, he backed off somewhat under pressure from free-trade Republicans. One way to read this is that Mexico and Canada have to show some more flexibility in the NAFTA talks - to give Trump some victories to ward off bigger disasters. If they go this way, the chance of a notice to withdraw declines. On the other hand, Mexico and Canada may feel emboldened by the support they received from most of the American political class in the tariff discussion and refuse to give in on the substantial issues. This would increase the chance of a notice - as a pressure instrument if nothing more. On the third hand, Trump showed once again his negotiating tactics - throw a big bomb first, alarm everybody, and then scale down the actual policy action. It's not inconceivable he may do the same with a notice to withdraw. But timing would be important here - if it's clear that the NAFTA talks cannot be finished on the original schedule and have to continue after the Mexican elections, will Trump issue the notice before the talks are finished? I think not - such a notice is not a vote-gainer for the Republican party overall (it may energize the anti-trade base, but will repel the business groups, and many Democrats are anti-trade as well). On balance, I still think the most likely scenario is that NAFTA talks continue through October 1 (and probably into 2019, after the new Mexican administration gets into office on Dec 1). But there is a chance that a notice is issued before the deadline, and this chance seems slightly larger than before the tariff episode.

I am forecasting 15% yes for this question because in my opinion the odds of the US providing notice of intent before 1 October 2018 are relatively low due to the unpopularity of this proposal. It puts thousands of American jobs in jeopardy and many trade experts agree it is not in the best interests of the US. Additionally, Trump alone cannot withdraw the US from NAFTA; given the nature of US domestic politics, this caveat makes notice of withdraw even more unlikely. However, a few upcoming events may cause Trump to become impatient and push to withdraw in the next few months. The current round of negotiations is supposed to end in March, and unless negotiations are completed by then or there is significant progress unanimously supported by the US, Mexico, and Canada, it will be difficult to implement reforms. Mexican presidential campaigns begin in March and elections will be held in July, during which time Mexico has said it will not ratify a new agreement. If the current political front-runner is elected, Mexico will likely adopt a stronger stance against Trump on trade. Additionally, notice of intent could be used by the Trump administration as a bargaining chip in negotiations to push concessions from Mexico and Canada. For these reasons, it is unlikely, but not impossible, that the US will provide notice of intent to withdraw from NAFTA in the next seven months.

This week, the sixth round of renegotiation talks for the North American Free Trade Agreement is scheduled to take place in Montreal, Canada. In the lead-up, both trade observers and markets careened from despair to relief as they assessed and reassessed NAFTA’s prospects.
Two weeks ago, Mexico’s currency weakened and some U.S. trade-related stocks fell on a report that Canada was increasingly convinced President Donald Trump would pull the United States out of NAFTA. On closer examination, it was not clear there was anything particularly novel in the report and the Canadian government denied holding such pessimistic views, but the episode demonstrated the deep-seated concern among investors watching closely.
For optimists, there were reassurances from Republican U.S. Senators to the contrary. Pat Roberts (R-KS), Chairman of the Senate Committee of Agriculture, said of the President, “I think he's seeing the big picture a lot better and the possible detrimental situation of what would occur if in fact he would terminate NAFTA.”
Politics. It is relatively easy to argue that NAFTA withdrawal would be a political disaster for the President. It would hit at many red states that are dependent on farm exports and form the core of his political support. It would also hit at the auto sector, disproportionately affecting states like Michigan. And some recent market wobbles suggest that there is at least a chance that the move could undermine the business optimism that has helped propel the stock market to lofty Yet what matters is the President’s perception of the politics, and he sees antipathy to trade as central to his appeal to his base. NAFTA’s fate may depend on how compelled he feels to fire up that base.

Three probability estimates govern my forecast:
 - the probability that NAFTA renegotiations will be completed before Oct 1 (I assign 20% here, as the Mexican elections in July will intervene - see my earlier post. May even reduce it further the next time);
 - the probability that the renegotiations will fail. Here I reduce my probability estimate from 75% to 60%. The US has quite a leverage over both Mexico and Canada, being the largest - by far - trading partner for both, so it's not inconceivable that some sort of an agreement can be reached, especially if the US negotiators moderate their demands a little. It's still less likely than 50/50, though. 
 - the probability that a notice will be provided if renegotiations fail. Here I keep 100%, as (i) if negotiations are allowed to fail (as opposed to being extended), this would mean that Trump has given up on an agreement; and (ii) if there is no chance of an agreement, Trump can't afford to do nothing - he would lose both face and credibility with his base.
